image.altText: A man stands on a balcony with a frown on his face.

items.synopsis: Insurance companies have responded to back-to-back floods and soaring building costs by hiking premiums by around 30 per cent in just one year. But for the riskiest homes, cover is either refused outright, or offered at prices few can afford.

title.children: 'Who can afford that?' Scott was quoted nearly $32K for home and contents insurance as premiums soar

image.altText: An elderly woman holds up a small poster that reads 'vote no', as part of a rally for the Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

items.synopsis: The No campaign has been accused of asking volunteers to spread "fear and misinformation" in an effort to convince referendum voters of its agenda.

title.children: Voice No campaign accused of asking volunteers to 'flat out lie'

image.altText: An AFL player in a black training shirt, catches a football

items.synopsis: Maynard's season will be over if Collingwood is unable to throw out the defender's ban for rough conduct. Follow live.

title.children: Brayden Maynard faces tribunal with his season in doubt over Brayshaw hit

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Brayden Maynard's hearing is under way at the AFL Tribunal.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The hearing has begun

children.content: Brayden Maynard's hearing is under way at the AFL Tribunal.

image.altText: A pharmacist standing behind a counter holding a prescription basket towards the camera

items.synopsis: Parents and carers are warned that a shortage affecting the most-prescribed antibiotics for children is set to continue until early next year.

title.children: The most-prescribed antibiotics for children are in critically short supply across the country

image.altText: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un waves from a private train.

items.synopsis: Kim Jong Un's trip to Russia by rail has drawn attention to the traditional method of travel for North Korean leaders — luxury, armoured trains that have long been a part of the dynasty's lore.

title.children: Kim Jong Un has arrived in Russia by rail. Here's a look at his luxury armoured train

image.altText: A drone shot of rows of houses in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

items.synopsis: After months of negotiations, the government’s signature housing promise is set to pass the Senate. So how many new homes will be built, how soon, and where across the country?

title.children: Where will these new homes be built? Here's what the government's new housing bill means for you

image.altText: A young man wearing a grey hoodie.

items.synopsis: A boy who repeatedly stabbed "typical, cheeky teenager" Declan Cutler during a deadly gang attack on a Melbourne street is jailed for 15 years.

title.children: Teens jailed over 'savage and totally unprovoked' fatal attack on Melbourne 16yo

image.altText: Doody Shucking

items.synopsis: A south coast oyster farmer who can shuck 30 in under three minutes hopes that's quick enough to beat the world's best.

title.children: Gerard Dennis grew up 600km from the coast, now he hopes to be crowned the best oyster shucker in the world

image.altText: A pregnant woman in a white dress with a horse on a beach.

items.synopsis: Emma Goyne believes she picked up the parasitic infection while cleaning her horse stable, which a neighbouring cat had been using as a litter box. Now she's pushing for tougher cat laws.

title.children: 'Cat poo on my hands': Emma fell sick when pregnant. She wants cat laws tightened

image.altText: A woman with a ponytail and dark long sleeve top standing in front of a tree

items.synopsis: An expert says there's been a spike in pneumonia infections in people with healthy immune systems. Circus performer Caitlyn Larsson, who had the infection for three months this year, is one of them.

title.children: Why are even healthy people getting sick with pneumonia this year?

image.altText: A middle-aged, bespectacled man in a suit exits a court building.

items.synopsis: Maurice Molan will be fined $2,500 after pleading guilty to misconduct in public office over the 2013 engagement of an allegedly fraudulent third-party training company.

title.children: Former executive avoids conviction over $1.8m TAFE scandal

image.altText: A man wearing a car backwards stands by a bright green car, with its doors open.

items.synopsis: Lawyers for the 32-year-old accused of stealing Nick Kyrgios's Tesla say police are taking too long to hand over the full brief of evidence and the case should be abandoned.

title.children: Canberra man accused of stealing Nick Kyrgios's Tesla wants case against him to be dropped

image.altText: An aerial view shows the charred remains of a building, with sparse trees nearby

items.synopsis: With a seemingly endless supply of guns, money and young men willing to act as mercenaries, tribal fighting in PNG has become akin to guerilla warfare.

title.children: Violence is so bad in this PNG community that police sealed it off to outsiders. The ABC got to go inside

image.altText: Soldiers attempt to tow a vehicle stuck in mud

items.synopsis: Harsh winter conditions will bring new challenges in the war in Ukraine. The fighting will not stop, but it will change its tempo — and both sides will face different tests, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: Napoleon and Hitler battled the Marshall Mud. Could it be Putin's undoing?

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

items.synopsis: Two tourism companies on trial over the deadly Whakaari White Island volcano eruption have had charges dismissed.

title.children: More White Island tourism companies have charges dismissed, just one defendant remains

image.altText: A woman in a red hat leaning on a rusty bar of a gate.

items.synopsis: Australia's richest person, Gina Rinehart, has increased her stake in lithium firm Liontown Resources as global lithium giant Albemarle seeks a buyout. Meanwhile, the ASX is trading sideways. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Gina Rinehart ups stake in lithium miner Liontown Resources in looming takeover battle, ASX treads water, consumer confidence falls

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Staying on superannuation, the nation's largest superannuation fund, AustralianSuper, is spending $2.5 billion to buy a minority stake in global data centre firm Vantage Data Centers. The move is the company's first significant investment in data centres, which house servers and hardware equipment. The super fund joins US investment manager Digital Bridge as a key shareholder in Vantage Data's Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA) business. Nik Kemp, head of infrastructure at AustralianSuper: "The Vantage EMEA platform is at an exciting point in its history, with a strong pipeline of developments in growing markets across the region. "The Vantage EMEA platform will complement our existing digital infrastructure investments and this acquisition represents an important step for the fund as we build out our infrastructure capability in Europe."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian Super

children.content: Staying on superannuation, the nation's largest superannuation fund, AustralianSuper, is spending $2.5 billion to buy a minority stake in global data centre firm Vantage Data Centers.
The move is the company's first significant investment in data centres, which house servers and hardware equipment.
The super fund joins US investment manager Digital Bridge as a key shareholder in Vantage Data's Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA) business.
Nik Kemp, head of infrastructure at AustralianSuper:
"The Vantage EMEA platform is at an exciting point in its history, with a strong pipeline of developments in growing markets across the region.

"The Vantage EMEA platform will complement our existing digital infrastructure investments and this acquisition represents an important step for the fund as we build out our infrastructure capability in Europe."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's the question my colleague Nassim Khadem is asking. Total superannuation assets are projected to almost triple to more than $9 trillion by 2041, according to a report by Deloitte. But as the influence of superannuation funds — economically and politically — continues to grow, transparency over how member money gets used becomes crucial. In 2021, the banking regulator found there was at times a lack of evidence to assess the benefits of marketing by super funds, including whether it resulted in improved outcomes for members. It's an important question to ask as the federal government moves to revamp the $3.5 trillion secto r and examines the lucrative tax breaks that predominately benefit the wealthy. Have a read of this thought provoking story:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Should superannuation funds be more accountable on how they spend your money?

featuredLink.title: With super assets set to top $9 trillion in 2041, should funds be more accountable about how they spend members' money?

children.content: That's the question my colleague
Nassim Khadem
is asking.
Total superannuation assets are projected to almost triple to
more than $9 trillion by 2041, according to a report by Deloitte.
But as the influence of superannuation funds — economically and politically — continues to grow,
transparency over how member money gets used becomes crucial.
In 2021, the banking regulator found there was at times a lack of evidence to assess the benefits of marketing by super funds, including whether it resulted in improved outcomes for members.

$3.5 trillion secto
r and examines the lucrative tax breaks that predominately benefit the wealthy.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This story is truly terrible and a great shame on our nation. It's about the lack of resources and priority for remote Indigenous communities. The family of a man who suffered a medical episode in remote East Arnhem Land in the Northern Territory were forced to drive his body more than 100 kilometres to the nearest hospital because an air ambulance was not available. The family repeatedly called triple-0 for medical assistance but they were eventually advised to take him to Gove District Hospital, a four hour drive along a unsealed dirt road. Respected elder Djambawa Marawili is the man's father in law. "If whitefella, something happened to [them], the flying doctor [could have come] at once, but for us for Indigenous people, we have to wait around." Here's more on this exclusive story by Natasha MacFarlane.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Call for more resources for remote communities after man dies on way to  hospital

featuredLink.title: Family forced to drive loved one's body more than four hours to remote hospital

children.content: This story is truly terrible and a great shame on our nation.
It's about the lack of resources and priority for remote Indigenous communities.

The family of a man who suffered a medical episode in remote East Arnhem Land in the Northern Territory were forced to drive his body more than 100 kilometres to the nearest hospital because an air ambulance was not available.
The family repeatedly called triple-0 for medical assistance but they were eventually advised to take him to Gove District Hospital, a four hour drive along a unsealed dirt road.
Respected elder Djambawa Marawili is the man's father in law.
"If whitefella, something happened to [them], the
flying doctor [could have come] at once, but for us for Indigenous people, we have to wait around."
Here's more on this exclusive story by Natasha MacFarlane.

image.altText: A mother and father with a child in a wheelchair, and another child on a swing.

items.synopsis: Barely two months ago, Spencer Barton was an active and energetic five-year-old — but a shock diagnosis has turned the lives of him and his parents upside down, and left them battling not only his condition but the health system.

title.children: 5yo's 'truly heartbreaking' health battle leaves his family struggling to secure support

image.altText: A man of Asian appearance wears glasses and stands speaking at a podium in a room, in front of a chalkboard and computer screens

items.synopsis: Banned from Australia over an alleged foreign interference plot in New South Wales, Chen Hong maintains he has done nothing wrong and continues to criticise the diplomatic stance taken by the former Coalition government.

title.children: Chinese scholar barred from Australia takes part in high-level dialogue between nations in Beijing

image.altText: Curtin Uni Wesley players stand arm in arm in a huddle during an Aussie rules match.

items.synopsis: Amateur female players call out derogatory and sexist online commentary after the Perth Football League A-grade grand final, saying "older men" are to blame for "disgusting" behaviour.

image.altText: Aaron Rodgers walks off the field with New York Jets trainers after injuring his ankle in their NFL season opener.

items.synopsis: Aaron Rodgers leaves the Jets' season opener with a suspected torn Achilles in the fourth minute after he arrived from Green Bay on a two-year deal worth $117 million.

title.children: The New York Jets paid more than $100 million for quarterback Aaron Rodgers. He lasted four plays

image.altText: Teammates congratulate a rugby league player after he scored a try

items.synopsis: One of them grew up in a Samoan village and didn't play a game of footy until he was 17. The other is a former reserve grade journeyman. Together, they're keeping the Roosters alive in 2023.

title.children: The unsung heroes keeping the Sydney Roosters improbable finals run alive

image.altText: junk food alongside healthy food

items.synopsis: The CSIRO report found construction workers had the poorest diets, while retirees and those in the fitness industry were the healthiest eaters.

title.children: Only 35pc of adults are eating enough veg, with alcohol and takeaway dominating diets, report finds

image.altText: A woman voting at night at a cardboard polling booth

items.synopsis: The governor-general has issued the writ for the Voice to Parliament referendum, setting in motion the time line for the nationwide vote.

title.children: Voice referendum key dates for postal and early votes have been confirmed. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Tom Curry is shown a yellow card

items.synopsis: Four games. Five similar incidents. Three different decisions. As rugby grapples with its head-contact rules, players and coaches plead for consistency, writes Simon Smale.

image.altText: A man sitting, looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Mustafa Chiahad's son was buried beneath the rubble of his parents' home in Talat N'Yaaqoub. The town, near the epicentre of Morocco's earthquake, has turned in to ground zero for destruction.

title.children: 'I don't have the words to describe it': Devastated families count cost of Morocco's quake

image.altText: A group of rescuers in a cave lift a man on a stretcher using ropes

items.synopsis: Rescuers have pulled an American researcher out of a Turkish cave more than a week after he became seriously ill 1,000 metres below its entrance, said the Speleological Federation of Türkiye.

title.children: 'I kept throwing up blood': Researcher stuck in cave thought he was not going to live

items.synopsis: Police are investigating after a 28-year-old man died while abseiling at Belmore Falls in Barrengarry.

title.children: Man dies after falling from a cliff while abseiling in Southern Highlands

image.altText: A teenager boy with a surfboard on a beach under an ocean pier

items.synopsis: Gold Coast teenager Kai Colless seals the world title in his division, winning the final of the US Adaptive Surfing Championships in California just eight months after leaving hospital.

title.children: Teen wins surfing world title one year after 'scary' diagnosis limits the use of his legs
